rel=&quot;nofollow&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot; title=&quot;Pin: Full Circle: Life Lessons of a Perennial Entrepreneur&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;a rel=&quot;nofollow&quot; class=&quot;perma-link&quot; href=&quot;https://heropress.com/essays/full-circle-life-lessons-perennial-entrepreneur/&quot; title=&quot;Full Circle: Life Lessons of a Perennial Entrepreneur&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;p&gt;The post &lt;a rel=&quot;nofollow&quot; href=&quot;https://heropress.com/essays/full-circle-life-lessons-perennial-entrepreneur/&quot;&gt;Full Circle: Life Lessons of a Perennial Entrepreneur&lt;/a&gt; appeared first on &lt;a rel=&quot;nofollow&quot; href=&quot;https://heropress.com&quot;&gt;HeroPress&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}s:7:&quot;pubDate&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:31:&quot;Wed, 07 Dec 2016 12:30:20 +0000&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}}s:32:&quot;http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/&quot;;a:1:{s:7:&quot;creator&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:19:&quot;Jackie D&amp;#8217;Elia&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}}}}i:14;a:6:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:13:&quot;
	
	
	
	
	
	
&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:5:&quot;child&quot;;a:2:{s:0:&quot;&quot;;a:5:{s:5:&quot;title&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:87:&quot;WPTavern: Pantheon’s $100K WordCamp US Sponsorship Revoked the Night Before the Event&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}s:4:&quot;guid&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:29:&quot;https://wptavern.com/?p=64248&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}s:4:&quot;link&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:94:&quot;https://wptavern.com/pantheons-100k-wordcamp-us-sponsorship-revoked-the-night-before-the-event&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}s:11:&quot;description&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:8493:&quot;&lt;p&gt;Nearly 2,000 people descended on Philadelphia, PA to attend WordCamp US last week. On the night before WordCamp US took place, &lt;a href=&quot;https://pantheon.io/&quot;&gt;Pantheon&amp;#8217;s&lt;/a&gt; sponsorship was revoked and advertising materials, including the company&amp;#8217;s booth, were hidden in a storage room inside the venue. The move generated a &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/danielbachhuber/status/804721149900890112&quot;&gt;lot of controversy&lt;/a&gt; on social media and at the event. It cost Pantheon $100K to sponsor WordCamp US, but the company received a refund.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;blockquote class=&quot;twitter-tweet&quot;&gt;
&lt;p lang=&quot;en&quot; dir=&quot;ltr&quot;&gt;Our booth disappeared but the team's still here! Look for us in yellow! &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/hashtag/WCUS?src=hash&quot;&gt;#WCUS&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;https://t.co/lnF5aI36oy&quot;&gt;pic.twitter.com/lnF5aI36oy&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&amp;mdash; Pantheon (@getpantheon) &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/getpantheon/status/804715506674626560&quot;&gt;December 2, 2016&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Prior to WordCamp US Matt Stodolnic, Pantheon&amp;#8217;s Vice President of Marketing, contacted the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sheratonphiladelphiadowntown.com/&quot;&gt;Sheraton Downtown Philadelphia&lt;/a&gt; and inquired about advertising opportunities. The Sheraton &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sheratonphiladelphiadowntown.com/philadelphia-meetings&quot;&gt;hosts a number of meetings&lt;/a&gt; and has a couple of different advertising packages available. Stodolnic purchased advertising space on the hotel&amp;#8217;s elevators. The advertising material was simple and didn&amp;#8217;t make unprovable claims, such as the world&amp;#8217;s best or fastest host. This is in line with the &lt;a href=&quot;https://make.wordpress.org/community/handbook/wordcamp-organizer/planning-details/fundraising/wordcamp-sponsorship/#wordcamp-sponsorship-rules-for-2016&quot;&gt;sponsorship rules&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;https://i0.wp.com/wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/PantheonElevatorAdvertising.png?ssl=1&quot;&gt;&lt;img class=&quot;size-full wp-image-64262&quot; src=&quot;https://i0.wp.com/wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/PantheonElevatorAdvertising.png?resize=629%2C806&amp;ssl=1&quot; alt=&quot;Pantheon's Elevator Advertising&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;Pantheon&amp;#8217;s Elevator Advertising
&lt;p&gt;On December 1st late at night, Stodolnic received an email from WCUS organizers requesting that the advertising material be removed. Stodolnic pushed back as the sponsorship agreement does not specifically prohibit advertising in the hotel. At one point during the exchange of emails, the WCUS organizing team threatened to take the banners down themselves. Stodolnic responded with anger as the purchase had already been made but he quickly apologized.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;The issue was eventually escalated to Matt Mullenweg, co-creator of the WordPress open source software project, who revoked the company&amp;#8217;s sponsorship of the event for violating the code of conduct. Later that night, WCUS organizers deconstructed Pantheon&amp;#8217;s booth and moved it to a storage room along with 600 T-shirts printed by the company.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;https://i1.wp.com/wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/PantheonsBoothBefore.png?ssl=1&quot;&gt;&lt;img class=&quot;size-full wp-image-64259&quot; src=&quot;https://i1.wp.com/wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/PantheonsBoothBefore.png?resize=981%2C734&amp;ssl=1&quot; alt=&quot;Pantheon's Booth at WCUS Before Being Taken Down&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;Pantheon&amp;#8217;s Booth at WCUS Before Being Taken Down
&lt;p&gt;Day one of WordCamp US went off without a hitch but it was slightly overshadowed by the sudden removal of Pantheon. A few Pantheon employees published unfavorable messages on Twitter about the situation. Those tweets have since been deleted. At the conclusion of day two, Cami Kaos, one of the lead organizers of WordCamp US, published a post on the &lt;a href=&quot;https://2016.us.wordcamp.org/&quot;&gt;event&amp;#8217;s blog&lt;/a&gt; highlighting what happened.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;https://i1.wp.com/wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/SponsorUpdatePost.png?ssl=1&quot;&gt;&lt;img class=&quot;size-full wp-image-64261&quot; src=&quot;https://i1.wp.com/wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/SponsorUpdatePost.png?resize=1004%2C739&amp;ssl=1&quot; alt=&quot;Archived Image of The Post Published on the WCUS Blog Explaining The Situation&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;Archived Image of The Post Published on the WCUS Blog Explaining The Situation
&lt;p&gt;The post doesn&amp;#8217;t specifically name Pantheon and says the sponsor in question violated the event&amp;#8217;s &lt;a href=&quot;https://2016.us.wordcamp.org/code-of-conduct/&quot;&gt;code of conduct&lt;/a&gt;. I spoke to a number of Pantheon employees who read the post and couldn&amp;#8217;t identify the violation in question. Within hours of being published, the post was removed from the site without an explanation.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h2&gt;Cooler Heads Prevail&lt;/h2&gt;
&lt;p&gt;During day two of WCUS, Stodolnic and Pantheon Co-founder Josh Koenig, spoke to Mullenweg face-to-face in a closed-door meeting at the venue. What was said is unknown but when I asked Mullenweg what the result of the meeting was, he said, &amp;#8220;I think we&amp;#8217;re in a much better place.&amp;#8221; He also didn&amp;#8217;t comment when asked how Pantheon violated the code of conduct.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;After the meeting, Stodolnic told me that both sides agreed that communication could have been handled better and that cooler heads prevailed. Mullenweg wouldn&amp;#8217;t comment when asked whether Pantheon was banned from sponsoring WordCamps in 2017.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;We now know that the official hotel for WordCamp US is an extension of the venue allowing organizers to enforce the code of conduct and sponsorship and principles agreements. It&amp;#8217;s likely that due to this incident, the sponsorship agreement will be amended to specifically prohibit advertising in the official hotel at next year&amp;#8217;s event.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Pantheon is a six-year old company making inroads in the managed WordPress hosting space. Not being able to sponsor WordCamps in 2017, &lt;a href=&quot;https://central.wordcamp.org/news/2016/03/28/pantheon-joins-the-wordpress-global-community-sponsorship-program-in-2016/&quot;&gt;as they did in 2016,&lt;/a&gt; could derail their momentum in building brand awareness.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h2&gt;Is It Worth It to Sponsor WordCamps?&lt;/h2&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Many of the sponsors I spoke to at WordCamp US described what Pantheon did as genius and were disappointed that they didn&amp;#8217;t think of it first. This opens the door to a wider conversation. Is it financially worth it to sponsor WordCamps and are there enough opportunities to see a return on investment?&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Earlier this year, Tony Perez, &lt;span class=&quot;st&quot;&gt;CEO of Sucuri, started a &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/perezbox/status/749283708209799168&quot;&gt;passionate discussion&lt;/a&gt; on Twitter around the value of sponsoring WordCamps. As the costs of sponsoring and the number of WordCamps increases, businesses will need to be more selective of which camps they sponsor.&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;blockquote class=&quot;twitter-tweet&quot;&gt;
&lt;p lang=&quot;en&quot; dir=&quot;ltr&quot;&gt;I think &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/hashtag/wordcamp?src=hash&quot;&gt;#wordcamp&lt;/a&gt; sponsorships and today's businesses will be coming to a cross roads in the the not so distant future.. &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/hashtag/wordpress?src=hash&quot;&gt;#wordpress&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&amp;mdash; Tony Perez (@perezbox) &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/perezbox/status/749283708209799168&quot;&gt;July 2, 2016&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;One of the &lt;a href=&quot;https://wptavern.com/state-of-the-word-2016-mullenweg-pushes-calypso-as-future-of-wordpress-interface-proposes-major-changes-to-release-cycle&quot;&gt;major announcements at WordCamp US&lt;/a&gt; is that WordCamps will now run finances through a &lt;a href=&quot;https://make.wordpress.org/community/handbook/wordcamp-organizer/first-steps/budget-and-finances/running-the-money-through-wpcs/&quot;&gt;Public Benefit Corporation&lt;/a&gt;. Previously, finances were run through the &lt;a href=&quot;http://wordpressfoundation.org/&quot;&gt;WordPress Foundation&lt;/a&gt;, a 501(c) non-profit entity which &lt;a href=&quot;https://make.wordpress.org/community/2016/03/02/transitioning-to-wordpress-community-support/&quot;&gt;severely limited&lt;/a&gt; what sponsors were able to do at events due to IRS regulations. When the switch occurred earlier this year, the &lt;a href=&quot;https://make.wordpress.org/community/handbook/wordcamp-organizer-handbook/planning-details/fundraising/wordcamp-sponsorship/#wordcamp-sponsorship-rules-for-2016&quot;&gt;sponsor rules were updated&lt;/a&gt; to be less restrictive.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;As WordCamps grow in size, especially WordCamp US, perhaps its time to rethink the benefits that are offered to sponsors to increase the sponsorship&amp;#8217;s value. What sponsorship opportunities would you like to see considered or added for WordCamps?&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div id=&quot;epoch-width-sniffer&quot;&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}s:7:&quot;pubDate&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:31:&quot;Wed, 07 Dec 2016 03:00:33 +0000&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}}s:32:&quot;http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/&quot;;a:1:{s:7:&quot;creator&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:13:&quot;Jeff Chandler&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}}}}i:15;a:6:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:13:&quot;
	
	
	
	
	
	
&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:5:&quot;child&quot;;a:2:{s:0:&quot;&quot;;a:5:{s:5:&quot;title&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:99:&quot;WPTavern: WordPress 4.7 Introduces Twenty Seventeen Default Theme and WP REST API Content Endpoints&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}s:4:&quot;guid&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:29:&quot;https://wptavern.com/?p=64226&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}s:4:&quot;link&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:110:&quot;https://wptavern.com/wordpress-4-7-introduces-twenty-seventeen-default-theme-and-wp-rest-api-content-endpoints&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}s:11:&quot;description&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:7624:&quot;&lt;a href=&quot;https://i1.wp.com/wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/sarah-vaughan.jpg?ssl=1&quot;&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i1.wp.com/wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/sarah-vaughan.jpg?resize=1025%2C645&amp;ssl=1&quot; alt=&quot;photo credit: Wikimedia Commons&quot; class=&quot;size-full wp-image-64229&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;photo credit: &lt;a href=&quot;https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Sarah_Vaughan_-_William_P._Gottlieb_-_No._1.jpg&quot;&gt;Wikimedia Commons&lt;/a&gt;
&lt;p&gt;WordPress 4.7 &amp;#8220;Vaughan&amp;#8221; was &lt;a href=&quot;https://wordpress.org/news/2016/12/vaughan/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;released&lt;/a&gt; today, named in honor of American jazz vocalist Sarah &amp;#8220;Sassy&amp;#8221; Vaughan. This release makes significant improvements to the new theme setup experience, inspiring the tagline: &amp;#8220;Your site, your way.&amp;#8221;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://wptavern.com/new-wordpress-default-theme-twenty-seventeen-merged-into-4-7&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Twenty Seventeen is making its debut in 4.7&lt;/a&gt; as the first default theme designed for business websites. It beautifully showcases new features for theme developers and demonstrates many improvements to the setup process. Twenty Seventeen offers four customizable panels on the front page for displaying existing content, custom logo upload, fullscreen featured images, and brand new core support for video headers.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;wp-video&quot;&gt;&lt;!--[if lt IE 9]&gt;&lt;script&gt;document.createElement('video');&lt;/script&gt;&lt;![endif]--&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;https://make.wordpress.org/core/files/2016/10/panels-ui-small.mp4&quot;&gt;https://make.wordpress.org/core/files/2016/10/panels-ui-small.mp4&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;Starter Content and Edit Shortcuts&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;WordPress 4.7 gives theme developers the ability to provide &lt;a href=&quot;https://make.wordpress.org/core/2016/11/30/starter-content-for-themes-in-4-7/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;starter content&lt;/a&gt;, such as a business info widget or a sample social icons menu. The content serves as a placeholder but doesn&amp;#8217;t appear on the live site until the user has customized and published it.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;New &lt;a href=&quot;https://wptavern.com/visible-edit-shortcuts-in-wordpress-4-7-makes-customizing-sites-easier&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;visible edit shortcuts&lt;/a&gt; display a pencil icon on areas of a theme that can be customized. Clicking the icons will automatically open the correct panel for the setting, which saves users time that might otherwise have been spent hunting around for the right setting to adjust. Theme authors will need to add theme support as well as support for selective refresh in order to take advantage of this new feature.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;https://i2.wp.com/wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/CustomizerShortcutButtons.png?ssl=1&quot;&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i2.wp.com/wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/CustomizerShortcutButtons.png?resize=1025%2C544&amp;ssl=1&quot; alt=&quot;Visible Edit Shortcut Buttons&quot; class=&quot;size-full wp-image-63883&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;Visible Edit Shortcut Buttons
&lt;p&gt;The new starter content and edit shortcuts features, especially when combined, give theme authors the ability to make customization easier and faster for their users. Themes with dozens of customizer options that may have previously seemed complicated to set up may now be more approachable.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;Improved Menu Building and Custom CSS with Live Previews&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;WordPress 4.7 &lt;a href=&quot;https://wptavern.com/new-wordpress-feature-proposal-adds-content-authorship-to-menus-in-the-customizer&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;adds content authorship to menus in the Customizer&lt;/a&gt;. Users can now create new pages while setting up menus, without having to navigate back to the admin. This makes for a smoother workflow when setting up a brand new site.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://wptavern.com/a-preview-of-the-custom-css-editor-added-to-the-customizer-in-wordpress-4-7&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Custom CSS with live previews&lt;/a&gt; is also new in this release. Users can now tweak the appearance of themes and plugins and see the results instantly. Those who have been using Jetpack&amp;#8217;s Custom CSS module should have a seamless migration. The new feature is fairly basic but extensible so &lt;a href=&quot;https://make.wordpress.org/core/2016/11/26/extending-the-custom-css-editor/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;plugin developers can add additional functionality&lt;/a&gt; on top of it.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;https://i1.wp.com/wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/WP47CustomizerCSSEditor.png?ssl=1&quot;&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i1.wp.com/wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/WP47CustomizerCSSEditor.png?resize=1025%2C394&amp;ssl=1&quot; alt=&quot;CSS Editor in The WordPress 4.7 Customizer&quot; class=&quot;size-full wp-image-63483&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;CSS Editor in The WordPress 4.7 Customizer
&lt;p&gt;WordPress 4.7 is packed full of many other user-facing improvements that make managing and editing content easier:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
&lt;li&gt;PDF thumbnail previews for better document management&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;li&gt;User admin languages&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;li&gt;Media library is now searchable by file name&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;li&gt;Improved Custom Background Properties UI (&lt;a href=&quot;https://core.trac.wordpress.org/ticket/22058&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;#22058&lt;/a&gt;)&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://make.wordpress.org/core/2016/10/28/editor-changes-in-4-7/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Editor changes&lt;/a&gt;: easier access to most-used buttons, improved discovery for keyboard shortcuts in tooltips and dropdowns&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;li&gt;Customizer sliding panels UI is now faster, smoother, and more accessible&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;li&gt;oEmbed support for Facebook posts/activities/photo/videos/media/questions/notes&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;WP REST API Content Endpoints Added to 4.7&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;One of the most exciting improvements to WordPress for developers is the addition of the &lt;a href=&quot;https://wptavern.com/wp-rest-api-officially-approved-for-merge-into-wordpress-4-7&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;WP REST API content endpoints&lt;/a&gt; for posts, comments, terms, users, meta, and settings. This API opens up new ways of accessing and presenting WordPress content in themes, plugins, and applications &amp;#8211; both inside and outside of the traditional WordPress interface. The WP REST API now has an &lt;a href=&quot;https://developer.wordpress.org/rest-api/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;official reference for documentation&lt;/a&gt; on WordPress.org.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;A few highlights of additional improvements for developers include the following:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://wptavern.com/wordpress-4-7-brings-custom-page-template-functionality-to-all-post-types&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Post Type Templates&lt;/a&gt; &amp;#8211; custom page template functionality is now available to all post types&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://wptavern.com/wordpress-4-7-will-allow-developers-to-register-custom-bulk-actions-in-admin-list-tables&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Custom bulk actions&lt;/a&gt; &amp;#8211; developers can register custom bulk actions for admin list tables&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://make.wordpress.org/core/2016/10/26/registering-your-settings-in-wordpress-4-7/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Expanded Settings Registration API&lt;/a&gt; via register_setting()&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://make.wordpress.org/core/2016/09/08/wp_hook-next-generation-actions-and-filters/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;WP_Hook overhaul&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;
&lt;p&gt;WordPress lead developer Helen Hou-Sandí led the 4.7 release with deputies Jeff Paul and Aaron Jorbin. A record-breaking 482 contributors had props on 4.7 and 205 of them were first-time contributors. More than 100 of those volunteers contributed to the Twenty Seventeen theme. Community translators made it possible for WordPress 4.7 to be available in 52 languages at release time and they also captioned the release video included below in 44 languages. Check out the &lt;a href=&quot;https://codex.wordpress.org/Version_4.7&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;4.7 codex page&lt;/a&gt; for a full rundown of all the new features and improvements in this release.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div id=&quot;epoch-width-sniffer&quot;&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}s:7:&quot;pubDate&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:31:&quot;Tue, 06 Dec 2016 21:25:53 +0000&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}}s:32:&quot;http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/&quot;;a:1:{s:7:&quot;creator&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:13:&quot;Sarah Gooding&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}}}}i:16;a:6:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:13:&quot;
	
	
	
	
	
	
&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:5:&quot;child&quot;;a:2:{s:0:&quot;&quot;;a:5:{s:5:&quot;title&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:51:&quot;Post Status: WordPress 4.7, “Vaughan”, released&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}s:4:&quot;guid&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:31:&quot;https://poststatus.com/?p=30979&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}s:4:&quot;link&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:46:&quot;https://poststatus.com/wordpress-4-7-released/&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}s:11:&quot;description&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:10113:&quot;&lt;p&gt;WordPress 4.7, “Vaughan”, &lt;a href=&quot;https://wordpress.org/news/2016/12/vaughan/&quot;&gt;has been released&lt;/a&gt;. It’s named, as always, after a famous jazz musician, and this release is named after &lt;a href=&quot;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Vaughan&quot;&gt;Sarah “Sassy” Vaughan&lt;/a&gt;, an American jazz singer.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;The Release Lead for WordPress 4.7 was &lt;a href=&quot;https://helen.blog/&quot;&gt;Helen Hou-Sandí&lt;/a&gt; &amp;#8212; who is also a WordPress Lead Developer, and the Director of Platform Experience at 10up. The Deputy Release Leads were &lt;a href=&quot;https://profiles.wordpress.org/jbpaul17&quot;&gt;Jeff Paul&lt;/a&gt;, a Team Lead at XWP, and &lt;a href=&quot;https://daily.jorb.in/&quot;&gt;Aaron Jorbin&lt;/a&gt;, the Director of Engineering at Some Spider. There were more than 475 total contributors to this release, and more than 200 were first time contributors!&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;As always, there&amp;#8217;s a &lt;a href=&quot;http://wordpress.tv/2016/12/06/introducing-wordpress-4-7-vaughan/&quot;&gt;release video&lt;/a&gt; that showcases the release highlights. This year, it was produced by Rami Abraham.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div id=&quot;v-AHz0Ca46-1&quot; class=&quot;video-player&quot;&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;img alt=&quot;Introducing WordPress 4.7&quot; src=&quot;https://videos.files.wordpress.com/AHz0Ca46/wp4-7-vaughan-r8-mastered_scruberthumbnail_0.jpg&quot; width=&quot;1024&quot; height=&quot;576&quot; /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;p&gt;Introducing WordPress 4.7&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;p&gt;WordPress 4.7 includes so many changes and new features worth highlighting, I will note a few of what I consider the most important and noteworthy, but it is not all-encompassing. This has been the most productive release in a very long time.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;WordPress REST API Content Endpoints&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;WordPress is now more extensible than ever before, thanks to the WordPress REST API and the Content Endpoints that have shipped with 4.7. The Content Endpoints are stage two of the REST API rollout, after the infrastructure was included &lt;a href=&quot;https://poststatus.com/wordpress-4-4/&quot;&gt;in WordPress 4.4&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;The Content Endpoints make it so developers can interact with all major content objects of WordPress: posts (including default and custom post types), terms, users, and comments.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;If you&amp;#8217;ve ever wanted to completely bypass the WordPress templating engine, now you can. You can use WordPress as a content store, and create a custom writing interface, or so many other things, thanks to this API that standardizes interfacing with WordPress.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;The implications for external applications are enormous. Third parties can now reliably anticipate how to work with any WordPress site.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;The WordPress REST API has reached a huge milestone, and &lt;a href=&quot;https://make.wordpress.org/core/2016/10/19/wordpress-rest-api-success-metrics/&quot;&gt;success metrics&lt;/a&gt; have been created to track how things are going with it. But the core team already knows there is much left to do.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;With the &lt;a href=&quot;https://poststatus.com/matt-mullenweg-state-word-2016/&quot;&gt;new development cycle&lt;/a&gt; Matt Mullenweg announced at WordCamp US just last week, the REST API will be one of three parts of WordPress that will have a major release dedicated to enhacing it. The goal is to expand the endpoints to include all site management features of WordPress, so that someone (or WordPress itself) could completely rebuild the WordPress administration experience from scratch, using the WordPress REST API.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;I sincerely believe the REST API is a gamechanger for WordPress. Now, it&amp;#8217;s your turn. Build stuff. Show the world what you&amp;#8217;ve made! There will be official WordPress REST API showcase efforts underway soon to capture what folks are building.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;This project would absolutely not have happened without the following people: Ryan McCue and Rachel Baker for leading the effort, Daniel Bachhuber and Joe Hoyle for their constant work and guidance, K. Adam White for a huge 4.7 effort in project management and wrangling, and Helen Hou-Sandí for making the call to include the API in the release.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Ready to get started with the WordPress REST API? The new &lt;a href=&quot;https://developer.wordpress.org/rest-api/&quot;&gt;REST API Handbook&lt;/a&gt; will be the home for documentation going forward.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;Twenty Seventeen&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Twenty Seventeen is the latest default theme for WordPress, and I believe the best since at least Twenty Twelve. The new default theme has a great multi-section front page feature that offers a great solution for small businesses to highlight their work in a single page format, with large featured images throughout.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img class=&quot;aligncenter wp-image-26479 size-large&quot; src=&quot;https://cdn.poststatus.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/twenty-seventeen-promo-752x313.png&quot; alt=&quot;twenty-seventeen-promo&quot; width=&quot;752&quot; height=&quot;313&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Twenty Seventeen was designed by Mel Choyce.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;Adjusted editor layout&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Many folks would consider it a minor change, but any change to the WordPress editor is a big one to me. As Andrew Ozz &lt;a href=&quot;https://make.wordpress.org/core/2016/10/28/editor-changes-in-4-7/&quot;&gt;highlights in the Make Core post&lt;/a&gt;, some of the buttons in the default editing toolbar have been moved around, based on statistics of usage.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img class=&quot;aligncenter size-large wp-image-30984&quot; src=&quot;https://cdn.poststatus.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/Screen-Shot-2016-12-06-at-1.24.48-PM-752x447.png&quot; alt=&quot;editor-toolbar-rearrangement&quot; width=&quot;752&quot; height=&quot;447&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Most notably, the headings drop down has been moved to the top row, and strikethrough and horizontal rule buttons have moved down. This is a good step in the right direction in supporting a better and easier to use editor.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;New Customizer features&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;The WordPress Customizer is another of the three feature focus areas moving forward in WordPress development. And there&amp;#8217;s a lot of new stuff in the Customizer with WordPress 4.7 that you should know about.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h4&gt;Video Headers&lt;/h4&gt;
&lt;p&gt;The new default theme supports &lt;a href=&quot;https://make.wordpress.org/core/2016/11/26/video-headers-in-4-7/&quot;&gt;video headers&lt;/a&gt;, a new feature in WordPress, managed within the customizer.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h4&gt;Visible Edit Shortcuts&lt;/h4&gt;
&lt;p&gt;The new visible edit shortcuts allow for someone using the customizer to see an icon next to the part of the page that is eligible to be edited in the customizer. It&amp;#8217;s perhaps a small UX addition, but will be very helpful for folks customizing their websites.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img class=&quot;aligncenter size-large wp-image-30982&quot; src=&quot;https://cdn.poststatus.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/Screen-Shot-2016-12-06-at-1.01.09-PM-752x405.png&quot; alt=&quot;customize-icon&quot; width=&quot;752&quot; height=&quot;405&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h4&gt;Create a Page Within a Menu&lt;/h4&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Finally, you can create pages from within the Menu Customizer. One of the most common site setup steps is to build your menu. But if you haven&amp;#8217;t already created the pages you want to put there, you have to go do that and come back.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Now users can create a page draft while in the Menu Customizer so that they don&amp;#8217;t have to take unnecessary steps or understand the order WordPress expects. Small wins like this are invaluable for the new user experience.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h4&gt;Custom CSS&lt;/h4&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Creating custom CSS straight from the editor has long been a popular Jetpack feature, and it was ported to WordPress core.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img class=&quot;aligncenter size-large wp-image-30981&quot; src=&quot;https://cdn.poststatus.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/Screen-Shot-2016-12-06-at-12.59.04-PM-752x438.png&quot; alt=&quot;wordpress-edit-css&quot; width=&quot;752&quot; height=&quot;438&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;This isn&amp;#8217;t exactly what I&amp;#8217;d call a best practice, but it&amp;#8217;s a common one. I&amp;#8217;ve used custom CSS myself many times, especially for small sites where I just wanted to get something small done quickly. This feature brings a common request to core, and helps someone customize their sites quicker and without a third party plugin.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h4&gt;Starter content for themes&lt;/h4&gt;
&lt;p&gt;I&amp;#8217;m really excited about the new starter content that WordPress themes can now include. This allows for smarter demos, so that the user better sees what the theme is designed for.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Helen has a whole post &lt;a href=&quot;https://make.wordpress.org/core/2016/11/30/starter-content-for-themes-in-4-7/&quot;&gt;describing exactly how it works&lt;/a&gt;, but this is another feature that takes something that was not great in WordPress (especially for free themes in the WordPress directory) and drastically improves it.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;I really look forward to seeing this in action, and look forward to see how adoption of this feature impacts both free and commercial WordPress theme ecosystems.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;Post type templates&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Pages have long support custom templates for WordPress themes to define, and now this feature has been &lt;a href=&quot;https://make.wordpress.org/core/2016/11/03/post-type-templates-in-4-7/&quot;&gt;extended to all post types&lt;/a&gt;, with opt-in support.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Now it&amp;#8217;s simple for theme authors to create a variety of templates so that content creators can pick and choose from a layout they want to utilize, just like they&amp;#8217;ve always done for pages.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;Check out the full field guide&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;WordPress 4.7 packs a lot of punch, and I highly recommend looking through the &lt;a href=&quot;https://make.wordpress.org/core/2016/12/05/wordpress-4-7-field-guide/&quot;&gt;full field guide&lt;/a&gt; on the various changes. I have not covered many of the developer focused features in this post, because Aaron has curated the Make Core posts that do a better job of it.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Also check out the &lt;a href=&quot;https://codex.wordpress.org/Version_4.7&quot;&gt;Codex page for WordPress 4.7&lt;/a&gt; for more information on features and links to specific tickets.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;hr /&gt;
&lt;p&gt;WordPress 4.7 is a monumental achievement and is the result of the efforts of hundreds.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Congratulations to Release Lead Helen Hou-Sandí, the core team, and all contributors. While the scheduled and strict-date releases worked really well and kept WordPress coming out on time every four months or so, I&amp;#8217;m excited to see how the new setup mixes things up for WordPress.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;This was a heck of a way to go out with the previous method.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Go &lt;a href=&quot;https://wordpress.org/download/&quot;&gt;download WordPress 4.7&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}s:7:&quot;pubDate&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:31:&quot;Tue, 06 Dec 2016 19:28:55 +0000&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}}s:32:&quot;http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/&quot;;a:1:{s:7:&quot;creator&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:15:&quot;Brian Krogsgard&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}}}}i:17;a:6:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:13:&quot;
	
	
	
	
	
	
&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:5:&quot;child&quot;;a:2:{s:0:&quot;&quot;;a:5:{s:5:&quot;title&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:37:&quot;Dev Blog: WordPress 4.7 “Vaughan”&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}s:4:&quot;guid&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:34:&quot;https://wordpress.org/news/?p=4596&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}s:4:&quot;link&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:43:&quot;https://wordpress.org/news/2016/12/vaughan/&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}s:11:&quot;description&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:40344:&quot;&lt;p&gt;Version 4.7 of WordPress, named “Vaughan” in honor of legendary jazz vocalist Sarah &amp;#8220;Sassy&amp;#8221; Vaughan, is available for download or update in your WordPress dashboard. New features in 4.7 help you get your site set up the way you want it.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div id=&quot;v-AHz0Ca46-1&quot; class=&quot;video-player&quot;&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;img alt=&quot;Introducing WordPress 4.7&quot; src=&quot;https://i1.wp.com/videos.files.wordpress.com/AHz0Ca46/wp4-7-vaughan-r8-mastered_scruberthumbnail_0.jpg?resize=632%2C354&amp;ssl=1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;p&gt;Introducing WordPress 4.7&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;hr /&gt;
&lt;h2&gt;Presenting Twenty Seventeen&lt;/h2&gt;
&lt;p&gt;A brand new default theme brings your site to life with immersive featured images and video headers.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img class=&quot;alignnone wp-image-4618 size-large&quot; src=&quot;https://i2.wp.com/wordpress.org/news/files/2016/12/4.7-—-Twenty-Seventeen-1.jpg?resize=632%2C356&amp;ssl=1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Twenty Seventeen focuses on business sites and features a customizable front page with multiple sections. Personalize it with widgets, navigation, social menus, a logo, custom colors, and more. Our default theme for 2017 works great in many languages, on any device, and for a wide range of users.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;hr /&gt;
&lt;h2&gt;Your Site, Your Way&lt;/h2&gt;
&lt;p&gt;WordPress 4.7 adds new features to the customizer to help take you through the initial setup of a theme, with non-destructive live previews of all your changes in one uninterrupted workflow.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;Theme Starter Content&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;wp-video&quot;&gt;&lt;!--[if lt IE 9]&gt;&lt;script&gt;document.createElement('video');&lt;/script&gt;&lt;![endif]--&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;https://wordpress.org/news/files/2016/12/starter-content.mp4&quot;&gt;https://wordpress.org/news/files/2016/12/starter-content.mp4&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;p&gt;To help give you a solid base to build from, individual themes can provide starter content that appears when you go to customize your brand new site. This can range from placing a business information widget in the best location to providing a sample menu with social icon links to a static front page complete with beautiful images. Don’t worry &amp;#8211; nothing new will appear on the live site until you’re ready to save and publish your initial theme setup.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;Edit Shortcuts&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;wp-video&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://wordpress.org/news/files/2016/12/edit-shortcuts.mp4&quot;&gt;https://wordpress.org/news/files/2016/12/edit-shortcuts.mp4&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Visible icons appear to show you which parts of your site can be customized while live previewing. Click on a shortcut and get straight to editing. Paired with starter content, getting started with customizing your site is faster than ever.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;div&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;Video Headers&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;wp-video&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://wordpress.org/news/files/2016/12/video-headers.mp4&quot;&gt;https://wordpress.org/news/files/2016/12/video-headers.mp4&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Sometimes a big atmospheric video as a moving header image is just what you need to showcase your wares; go ahead and try it out with Twenty Seventeen. Need some video inspiration? Try searching for sites with video headers available for download and use.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;div&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;Smoother Menu Building&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img class=&quot;wp-image-4606 size-medium alignright&quot; src=&quot;https://i1.wp.com/wordpress.org/news/files/2016/12/4.7-—-Nav.jpg?resize=300%2C158&amp;ssl=1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Many menus for sites contain links to the pages of your site, but what happens when you don’t have any pages yet? Now you can add new pages while building menus instead of leaving the customizer and abandoning your changes. Once you’ve published your customizations, you’ll have new pages ready for you to fill with content.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;div&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;Custom CSS&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img class=&quot;wp-image-4607 size-medium alignright&quot; src=&quot;https://i1.wp.com/wordpress.org/news/files/2016/12/4.7-—-CSS.jpg?resize=300%2C158&amp;ssl=1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Sometimes you just need a few visual tweaks to make your site perfect. WordPress 4.7 allows you to add custom CSS and instantly see how your changes affect your site. The live preview allows you to work quickly without page refreshes slowing you down.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;hr /&gt;
&lt;div&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;PDF Thumbnail Previews&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img class=&quot;wp-image-4609 size-medium alignright&quot; src=&quot;https://i1.wp.com/wordpress.org/news/files/2016/12/4.7-—-PDF.jpg?resize=300%2C158&amp;ssl=1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Managing your document collection is easier with WordPress 4.7. Uploading PDFs will generate thumbnail images so you can more easily distinguish between all your documents.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;div&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;Dashboard in your language&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img class=&quot;wp-image-4608 size-medium alignright&quot; src=&quot;https://i2.wp.com/wordpress.org/news/files/2016/12/4.7-—-Language.jpg?resize=300%2C158&amp;ssl=1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Just because your site is in one language doesn’t mean that everybody helping manage it prefers that language for their admin. Add more languages to your site and a user language option will show up in your user’s profiles.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;hr /&gt;
&lt;h2&gt;Introducing REST API Content Endpoints&lt;/h2&gt;
&lt;p&gt;WordPress 4.7 comes with REST API endpoints for posts, comments, terms, users, meta, and settings.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img class=&quot;size-large wp-image-4600 alignnone&quot; src=&quot;https://i2.wp.com/wordpress.org/news/files/2016/12/4.7-—-API.jpg?resize=632%2C205&amp;ssl=1&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Content endpoints provide machine-readable external access to your WordPress site with a clear, standards-driven interface, paving the way for new and innovative methods of interacting with sites through plugins, themes, apps, and beyond. Ready to get started with development? &lt;a href=&quot;https://developer.wordpress.org/rest-api/reference/&quot;&gt;Check out the REST API reference.&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;hr /&gt;
&lt;h2&gt;Even More Developer Happiness &lt;img src=&quot;https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/2.2.1/72x72/1f60a.png&quot; alt=&quot;?&quot; class=&quot;wp-smiley&quot; /&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://make.wordpress.org/core/2016/11/03/post-type-templates-in-4-7/&quot;&gt;Post Type Templates&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;By opening up the page template functionality to all post types, theme developers have even more flexibility with the WordPress template hierarchy.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;More Theme API Goodies&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;WordPress 4.7 includes &lt;a href=&quot;https://make.wordpress.org/core/2016/09/09/new-functions-hooks-and-behaviour-for-theme-developers-in-wordpress-4-7/&quot;&gt;new functions, hooks, and behavior&lt;/a&gt; for theme developers.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://make.wordpress.org/core/2016/10/04/custom-bulk-actions/&quot;&gt;Custom Bulk Actions&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;List tables, now with more than bulk edit and delete.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://make.wordpress.org/core/2016/09/08/wp_hook-next-generation-actions-and-filters/&quot;&gt;&lt;code&gt;WP_Hook&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;The code that lies beneath actions and filters has been overhauled and modernized, fixing bugs along the way.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;Settings Registration API&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;register_setting() &lt;a href=&quot;https://make.wordpress.org/core/2016/10/26/registering-your-settings-in-wordpress-4-7/&quot;&gt;has been enhanced&lt;/a&gt; to include type, description, and REST API visibility.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://make.wordpress.org/core/2016/10/12/customize-changesets-technical-design-decisions/&quot;&gt;Customize Changesets&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Customize changesets make changes in the customizer persistent, like autosave drafts. They also make exciting new features like starter content possible.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;hr /&gt;
&lt;h2&gt;The Squad&lt;/h2&gt;
&lt;p&gt;This release was led by &lt;a href=&quot;https://helen.blog&quot;&gt;Helen Hou-Sandí&lt;/a&gt;, backed up by &lt;a href=&quot;https://profiles.wordpress.org/jbpaul17&quot;&gt;Jeff Paul&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;http://aaron.jorb.in/&quot;&gt;Aaron Jorbin&lt;/a&gt; as Release Deputies, and with the help of these fine individuals. There are 482 contributors with props in this release—the most ever—with 205 of them contributing for the first time. Pull up some sassy Sarah Vaughan on your music service of choice, and check out some of their profiles:&lt;/p&gt;

href=&quot;https://profiles.wordpress.org/sudar&quot;&gt;Sudar Muthu&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://profiles.wordpress.org/patilswapnilv&quot;&gt;Swapnil V. Patil&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://profiles.wordpress.org/takahashi_fumiki&quot;&gt;Takahashi Fumiki&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://profiles.wordpress.org/miyauchi&quot;&gt;Takayuki Miyauchi&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://profiles.wordpress.org/karmatosed&quot;&gt;Tammie Lister&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://profiles.wordpress.org/tapsboy&quot;&gt;tapsboy&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://profiles.wordpress.org/tlovett1&quot;&gt;Taylor Lovett&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://profiles.wordpress.org/team&quot;&gt;team&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://profiles.wordpress.org/tg29359&quot;&gt;tg29359&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://profiles.wordpress.org/tharsheblows&quot;&gt;tharsheblows&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://profiles.wordpress.org/the&quot;&gt;the&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://profiles.wordpress.org/themeshaper&quot;&gt;themeshaper&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a &lt;a href=&quot;https://profiles.wordpress.org/transl8or&quot;&gt;transl8or&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://profiles.wordpress.org/traversal&quot;&gt;traversal&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://profiles.wordpress.org/websupporter&quot;&gt;websupporter&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://profiles.wordpress.org/westonruter&quot;&gt;Weston Ruter&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://profiles.wordpress.org/earnjam&quot;&gt;William Earnhardt&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://profiles.wordpress.org/williampatton&quot;&gt;williampatton&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://profiles.wordpress.org/youknowriad&quot;&gt;youknowriad&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://profiles.wordpress.org/oxymoron&quot;&gt;Zach Wills&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://profiles.wordpress.org/tollmanz&quot;&gt;Zack Tollman&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://profiles.wordpress.org/vanillalounge&quot;&gt;Ze Fontainhas&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://profiles.wordpress.org/zhildzik&quot;&gt;zhildzik&lt;/a&gt;, and &lt;a href=&quot;https://profiles.wordpress.org/zsusag&quot;&gt;zsusag&lt;/a&gt;.
&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br /&gt;
Special thanks go to &lt;a href=&quot;https://ramiabraham.com/&quot;&gt;Rami Abraham&lt;/a&gt; for producing the release video and the many fine haiku we saw in the &lt;a href=&quot;https://wordpress.org/news/2016/10/wordpress-4-7-beta-1/&quot;&gt;beta&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://wordpress.org/news/2016/11/wordpress-4-7-release-candidate/&quot;&gt;RC&lt;/a&gt; announcement posts.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Finally, thanks to all the community translators who worked on WordPress 4.7. Their efforts bring WordPress 4.7 fully translated to 52 languages at release time with more on the way. Additionally, the WordPress 4.7 release video has been captioned into 44 languages.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;If you want to follow along or help out, check out &lt;a href=&quot;https://make.wordpress.org/&quot;&gt;Make WordPress&lt;/a&gt; and our &lt;a href=&quot;https://make.wordpress.org/core/&quot;&gt;core development blog&lt;/a&gt;. Thanks for choosing WordPress &amp;#8211; we hope you enjoy!&lt;/p&gt;&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}s:7:&quot;pubDate&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:31:&quot;Tue, 06 Dec 2016 19:27:41 +0000&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}}s:32:&quot;http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/&quot;;a:1:{s:7:&quot;creator&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:15:&quot;Helen Hou-Sandi&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}}}}i:18;a:6:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:13:&quot;
	
	
	
	
	
	
&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:5:&quot;child&quot;;a:2:{s:0:&quot;&quot;;a:5:{s:5:&quot;title&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:135:&quot;WPTavern: State of the Word 2016: Mullenweg Pushes Calypso as Future of WordPress’ Interface, Proposes Major Changes to Release Cycle&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}s:4:&quot;guid&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:29:&quot;https://wptavern.com/?p=64185&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}s:4:&quot;link&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:141:&quot;https://wptavern.com/state-of-the-word-2016-mullenweg-pushes-calypso-as-future-of-wordpress-interface-proposes-major-changes-to-release-cycle&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}s:11:&quot;description&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:14793:&quot;&lt;a href=&quot;https://i0.wp.com/wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/sotw-2016.jpg?ssl=1&quot;&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i0.wp.com/wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/sotw-2016.jpg?resize=1025%2C487&amp;ssl=1&quot; alt=&quot;photo credit: WordCamp US organizing team&quot; class=&quot;size-full wp-image-64217&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;photo credit: &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/WordCampUS/status/805156416935882752&quot;&gt;WordCamp US organizing team&lt;/a&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Philadelphia welcomed 1,923 attendees to WordCamp US this weekend with an additional 2,028 enthusiasts watching via live stream. Matt Mullenweg delivered his 11th annual State of the Word address to a rapt audience ready to celebrate WordPress&amp;#8217; progress over the past year and hear the project leader&amp;#8217;s vision for 2017.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;He began by thanking sponsors and volunteers who made the event possible by covering the bulk of the $516 actual cost per person. Mullenweg said sponsors cover roughly 85-95% of the cost of WordCamps worldwide. In 2016, the events sold a total 36,000 tickets, with costs subsidized by more than 1,000 sponsors.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Mullenweg said meetups are the leading indicator for WordCamps and these events have had the fastest growth the community has seen in five or six years. More than 62,566 people attended a local meetup in 58 countries and roughly one third of those were new members.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;blockquote class=&quot;twitter-tweet&quot;&gt;
&lt;p lang=&quot;en&quot; dir=&quot;ltr&quot;&gt;It’s been a great year for WordCamps and meetups &amp;#8211; 115 total WordCamps hosted in 41 different countries. &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/hashtag/wcus?src=hash&quot;&gt;#wcus&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;https://t.co/yVGkT0j52C&quot;&gt;pic.twitter.com/yVGkT0j52C&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&amp;mdash; WordCamp US (@WordCampUS) &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/WordCampUS/status/805156784763715584&quot;&gt;December 3, 2016&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;WordPress Foundation to Create WordPress Community Support Subsidiary&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;In order to better accommodate the extraordinary growth of the global community, the WordPress Foundation will be restructuring its management of WordCamps. In 2016 the Foundation took in an estimated $4.3 million, up from $2.8 million in 2015, with 99.9% of those funds related to WordCamps. Mullenweg announced that the 501c nonprofit will move WordCamps to its own company, WordPress Community Support, forming a PBC (Public Benefit Corporation) that is fully owned by the Foundation.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;He explained that if certain things happened at WordCamps it could endanger the overall Foundation, so WordCamps will now be managed under their own entity where the events will have a little more flexibility in how they do things. The Foundation plans to support some like-minded nonprofits that are aligned with the overall education mission of the organization, including &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.hackthehood.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Hack the Hood&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://archive.org/index.php&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Internet Archive&lt;/a&gt;, and &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.blackgirlscode.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Black Girls Code&lt;/a&gt;. In 2017 the Foundation will also begin promoting hackathons to help nonprofits and NGO&amp;#8217;s.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;blockquote class=&quot;twitter-tweet&quot;&gt;
&lt;p lang=&quot;en&quot; dir=&quot;ltr&quot;&gt;The Foundation will focus on supporting like-minded non-profits, education/workshops, and hackathons that benefit non-profits/NGOs. &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/hashtag/wcus?src=hash&quot;&gt;#wcus&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;https://t.co/6VfdP82KuM&quot;&gt;pic.twitter.com/6VfdP82KuM&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&amp;mdash; WordCamp US (@WordCampUS) &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/WordCampUS/status/805158678353608704&quot;&gt;December 3, 2016&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;Internationalization is Driving an Increase in Plugin Usage&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Mullenweg shared a few stats about the plugin directory, which will soon be launching a new design with revamped search functionality. This year has seen a 20% increase in active plugin usage and a 34% increase in plugin downloads totaling 1.48 billion, which Mullenweg attributed to a spike in internationalization efforts over the past year. The number of translation contributors has grown from 5,000 in April 2015 to 17,000 as of November 2016.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;This year there were 1,598 plugins with language packs (up from 314 last year) and 1224 themes with language packs (up from 641 last year). Mullenweg noted that 2/3 of the world speaks one of 12 languages with native fluency and that WordPress covers all of these and many more. In fact, the 4.6 release shipped with support for 50 available languages. WordPress&amp;#8217; top 10 plugins are now 82% complete in the top 12 languages.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;blockquote class=&quot;twitter-tweet&quot;&gt;
&lt;p lang=&quot;en&quot; dir=&quot;ltr&quot;&gt;The top 10 plugins are 82% complete in the top 12 languages. &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/hashtag/wcus?src=hash&quot;&gt;#wcus&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;https://t.co/LnpEGv0p7o&quot;&gt;pic.twitter.com/LnpEGv0p7o&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&amp;mdash; WordCamp US (@WordCampUS) &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/WordCampUS/status/805161007349985280&quot;&gt;December 3, 2016&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;Mullenweg Continues to Push Calypso as the Future of the WordPress Interface&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;During the &lt;a href=&quot;https://wptavern.com/state-of-the-word-2015-javascript-and-api-driven-interfaces-are-the-future-of-wordpress&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2015 State of the Word&lt;/a&gt;, Mullenweg gave attendees a homework assignment to &amp;#8220;learn JavaScript deeply&amp;#8221; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://youtu.be/TX6dXRL-jPU?t=59m14s&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;promised to submit a JavaScript patch before 4.7&lt;/a&gt; came out. He submitted his first pull request to Calypso yesterday, Automattic&amp;#8217;s from-scratch rewrite of WP admin using Node and React.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;WordPress.com users have widely adopted the new interface for publishing. Mullenweg shared statistics showing that 68% of posts went through Calypso since its launch, 17% via mobile, and 15% through the traditional wp-admin. Mobile app and mobile browser usage are also up. &amp;#8220;We now need to start thinking about mobile devices as the primary way people are going to interact with WordPress in the future,&amp;#8221; Mullenweg said.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;From the time it launched, Mullenweg has said that Calypso, or something like it, would be the future of the WordPress interface. He reiterated this in his 2016 address and has committed some of Automattic&amp;#8217;s JavaScript developers from the Calypso team to contribute full-time to core.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;If Calypso has a chance at becoming a promising replacement for the WordPress admin, its creators will need to broaden its interoperability with the WordPress plugin ecosystem. Mullenweg announced that Calypso is now plugin aware and is open to plugins with over 1M active sites.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;The next step on Calypso&amp;#8217;s roadmap is to bring in support for Automattic&amp;#8217;s plugins &amp;#8211; WooCommerce, Akismet, Jetpack, and VaultPress. Mullenweg said the big focus for 2017 is to make plugins Calypso-aware, starting with a handful of the most popular ones before opening it up to all plugins.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&amp;#8220;The hope is that Calypso, or something like it, is actually what becomes the interface that drives WordPress,&amp;#8221; Mullenweg said. Since no one is currently building anything like Calypso and targeting core, it looks like the technology behind WordPress.com will be driving the evolution of WordPress in 2017.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;If Mullenweg&amp;#8217;s goal is to make Calypso the primary publishing engine for core WordPress, one of the major challenges will be getting plugin developers on board with building compatibility for what is currently an Automattic product. What are the implications of contributing to greater Calypso adoption? If core brings in the Calypso interface in the future, would Automattic push to include its Reader and other WordPress.com functionality, as it has in the mobile apps? These are questions developers will need to weigh when considering whether to pursue a more application-type experience via the Calypso interface.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;blockquote class=&quot;twitter-tweet&quot;&gt;
&lt;p lang=&quot;en&quot; dir=&quot;ltr&quot;&gt;What's next for Calypso? We'll start bringing &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/automattic&quot;&gt;@Automattic&lt;/a&gt;'s plugins in. &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/hashtag/wcus?src=hash&quot;&gt;#wcus&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;https://t.co/RL8ZduRczM&quot;&gt;pic.twitter.com/RL8ZduRczM&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&amp;mdash; WordCamp US (@WordCampUS) &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/WordCampUS/status/805165388006887424&quot;&gt;December 3, 2016&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;WordPress Recommends Hosts Offering PHP 7+ and HTTPS by Default&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;WordPress core continues to update its recommendations and requirements with the help of hosts who are adopting the latest technologies. The &lt;a href=&quot;https://wordpress.org/about/requirements/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;official recommendation for WordPress hosting&lt;/a&gt; is now PHP 7 or higher. After WordPress.com switched to be 100% on PHP 7, Mullenweg said the network&amp;#8217;s performance doubled and CPU load fell in half. Just 4% of self-hosted sites are on PHP 7, but the new recommendation should help move more hosts towards getting their customers updated.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;blockquote class=&quot;twitter-tweet&quot;&gt;
&lt;p lang=&quot;en&quot; dir=&quot;ltr&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://t.co/VrQffeOtG0&quot;&gt;https://t.co/VrQffeOtG0&lt;/a&gt; has been 100% switched over to PHP7, bringing significant performance improvements. &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/hashtag/wcus?src=hash&quot;&gt;#wcus&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;https://t.co/MChiS9QBJh&quot;&gt;pic.twitter.com/MChiS9QBJh&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&amp;mdash; WordCamp US (@WordCampUS) &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/WordCampUS/status/805164029371158528&quot;&gt;December 3, 2016&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Beginning in 2017, WordPress will have progressive enhancement for certain features that are only available for encrypted sites. Mullenweg announced that WordPress.org is now tracking HTTPS adoption. So far 11.45% of active WordPress websites are on HTTPS and &lt;a href=&quot;https://wptavern.com/wordpress-will-only-recommend-hosting-companies-offering-ssl-by-default-in-2017&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;the project will no longer recommend hosts that do not offer it by default&lt;/a&gt;. &amp;#8220;We want to bring more of the web to be secure, which is especially important in the post-Snowden era,&amp;#8221; he said.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;Trying New Things: Major Changes Coming to WordPress&amp;#8217; Core Release Cycle&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;WordPress 4.7 release lead Helen Hou-Sandí joined Mullenweg on stage to highlight a few of the features and improvements that will be coming in the official release on Tuesday. The release is arguably one of the most exciting and successful updates for WordPress in some time, but Mullenweg has a new strategy for core development in 2017.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&amp;#8220;We&amp;#8217;re at a junction for WordPress where what got us here wont get us there,&amp;#8221; Mullenweg said, after highlighting how the software&amp;#8217;s market share has grown from 13.1% to 27.2% in the past five years.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Mullenweg proposed a new structure for WordPress releases where design and user testing will lead the way. &amp;#8220;I&amp;#8217;m putting back on the &amp;#8216;product lead&amp;#8217; hat for 2017,&amp;#8221; he said. The upcoming year will have no set release schedule. Mullenweg is upending WordPress&amp;#8217; predictable release cycle in favor of tackling some larger items on the to-do list. He said the focus will be on performance and fixes to existing functionality in three main focus areas: WP REST API, the Editor, and the Customizer.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Mullenweg said he is particularly interested in getting first-party usage of the REST API in the admin, in hopes of having it evolve to something the project can use for the next decade. If it doesn&amp;#8217;t, he said core will consider bringing it back into a plugin specifically for developers.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Mullenweg said he feels the editor does not represent the core of WordPress publishing, a sentiment that many users agree with. He hopes to steer it toward a more block-based approach that unifies widgets and includes an interface for shortcodes.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Mullenweg&amp;#8217;s vision for the Customizer is to see all aspects of WordPress become more instant and provide the same interface and UI affordances as the editor. He announced that Ephox, the company behind TinyMCE, has agreed to work with the project to improve the core editing experience.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Shifting from a time-based release cycle to one that is more project-based is a major departure from WordPress&amp;#8217; previous release philosophy of &amp;#8220;Deadlines are not arbitrary.&amp;#8221; The project&amp;#8217;s &lt;a href=&quot;https://wordpress.org/about/philosophy/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;philosophy page&lt;/a&gt; identifies the practice of delaying releases for one more feature as a &amp;#8220;rabbit hole&amp;#8221; that has been tested and found to be unpleasant. The new approach to core development makes no guarantee that WordPress will have any releases in 2017.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;If the experiment is not a success, the project&amp;#8217;s days of frequent and fast iteration may be over for awhile. Mullenweg is willing to risk it in hopes of being able to provide more product-based leadership that will distinguish WordPress from its proprietary competitors.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;blockquote class=&quot;twitter-tweet&quot;&gt;
&lt;p lang=&quot;en&quot; dir=&quot;ltr&quot;&gt;Words of wisdom from &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/kristatippett&quot;&gt;@kristatippett&lt;/a&gt;: &quot;We only learn to walk when we risk falling down&amp;#8211;&quot; &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/hashtag/wcus?src=hash&quot;&gt;#wcus&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;https://t.co/6t5sD6Xjbm&quot;&gt;pic.twitter.com/6t5sD6Xjbm&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&amp;mdash; WordCamp US (@WordCampUS) &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/WordCampUS/status/805170327726780416&quot;&gt;December 3, 2016&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&amp;#8220;I think we&amp;#8217;re trying to counter stagnation,&amp;#8221; Mullenweg said when asked about the new approach to releases in the Q&amp;amp;A segment. &amp;#8220;Even though we&amp;#8217;ve had lots of releases, certain parts of WordPress have stagnated and haven&amp;#8217;t made the leaps that they could.&amp;#8221;  He suggested that being part of a feature plugin team will give developers a way to be involved in more active releases and continue to build momentum for eventual inclusion of their projects in core.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Mullenweg plans to identify a tech lead and a design lead and will be working with them as the overall product lead. He envisions that when one area of WordPress gets to the point where the software can ship significant user-facing improvements, a release will be born.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&amp;#8220;We&amp;#8217;re at the point now where the steps WordPress needs to take are more significant to get the other 73% of the web it doesn&amp;#8217;t have yet,&amp;#8221; Mullenweg said.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;In a return to WordPress&amp;#8217; poetic roots, he concluded by reading a poem called &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.poets.org/poetsorg/poem/praise-song-day&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Praise Song&lt;/a&gt; for the Day by Elizabeth Alexander.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;The video of the State of the Word address will soon be available on &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCpJf6LGZ0a4n9Lj4aVt9spg&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;WordPress&amp;#8217; new YouTube channel&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div id=&quot;epoch-width-sniffer&quot;&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}s:7:&quot;pubDate&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:31:&quot;Sun, 04 Dec 2016 18:50:17 +0000&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}}s:32:&quot;http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/&quot;;a:1:{s:7:&quot;creator&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:13:&quot;Sarah Gooding&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}}}}i:19;a:6:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:13:&quot;
	
	
	
	
	
	
&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:5:&quot;child&quot;;a:2:{s:0:&quot;&quot;;a:5:{s:5:&quot;title&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:51:&quot;Post Status: Matt Mullenweg State of the Word, 2016&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}s:4:&quot;guid&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:31:&quot;https://poststatus.com/?p=30865&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}s:4:&quot;link&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:54:&quot;https://poststatus.com/matt-mullenweg-state-word-2016/&quot;;s:7:&quot;attribs&quot;;a:0:{}s:8:&quot;xml_base&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;s:17:&quot;xml_base_explicit&quot;;b:0;s:8:&quot;xml_lang&quot;;s:0:&quot;&quot;;}}s:11:&quot;description&quot;;a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:&quot;data&quot;;s:16796:&quot;&lt;p&gt;Matt Mullenweg just completed the 2016 State of the Word presentation at WordCamp US 2016.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;This year, Matt focused on a variety of important topics, including the state of user experience in WordPress today, goals for future interface improvements, a WordPress growth council, internationalization gains, the further proliferation of secure websites, and important changes to the WordPress development process.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;WordCamp US in Philadelphia&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Matt began his talk by thanking the city of Philadelphia for being a great host of the first two WordCamp US events, as well as the sponsors, organizers, and volunteers that helped make WordCamp US one of the most successful and smoothest run WordCamps ever.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;He also said the per person cost for WordCamp US is over $500 per person, and that only the sponsors make that happen. And next year, WordCamp US is making its way to Nashville.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;WordCamps and meetups in 2016&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;There were 116 WordCamps in 2016, and over 36,000 attendees, 2,056 speakers, 1,036 sponsors, and 750 organizers.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;There were 3,193 meetup events in 58 countries. These were attended by more than 62,000 people, or nearly double WordCamps.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Matt says it&amp;#8217;s the fastest growth there has been for these events in around five or six years. WordCamp Europe actually had more people than WordCamp US this year, which Matt took as a personal challenge for Nashville.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://wordpress.tv/&quot;&gt;WordPress.tv&lt;/a&gt; published 26% more talks this year than the previous year, and now there is an official &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/wordpress&quot;&gt;WordPress channel on YouTube&lt;/a&gt;, so more and more videos will begin to be available wherever people want to watch them.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;WordCamp public benefit corporation and the WordPress Foundation&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;More than a year ago, work began to separate WordCamps from the &lt;a href=&quot;http://wordpressfoundation.org/&quot;&gt;WordPress Foundation&lt;/a&gt;, in order to make WordPress event organizing more flexible and to better protect the WordPress trademarks that the foundation holds.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;One of the things the foundation is going to start doing is support like minded non-profits, and in 2017 will be sponsoring three: Hack the Hood, the Internet Archive, and Black Girls Code.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Also, the foundation will start to promote hackathons for non-profits and NGOs.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;WordPress&amp;#8217;s extended family&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Matt gave a shoutout to WordPress&amp;#8217;s &amp;#8220;cousins&amp;#8221; like BuddyPress and bbPress, highlighting a lot of features that have gone into the software in the last year.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h4&gt;BuddyPress and bbPress&lt;/h4&gt;
&lt;p&gt;WordPress.org itself uses BuddyPress and bbPress. For ages, it&amp;#8217;s used outdated versions of bbPress, and in the past year launched a new support form that uses modern bbPress and WordPress profiles use bbPress. Matt says projects like these will get new support and engagement over the next year.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h4&gt;HackerOne&lt;/h4&gt;
&lt;p&gt;HackerOne is a security website that allows software organizations to offer bounties to hackers for responsibly disclosing security bugs.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h4&gt;GlotPress&lt;/h4&gt;
&lt;p&gt;GlotPress has had a big transformation in the last year, as it is no longer standalone software on top of BackPress, but rather a plugin for WordPress. If you&amp;#8217;ve never been to &lt;a href=&quot;https://translate.wordpress.org/&quot;&gt;translate.WordPress.org&lt;/a&gt;, you&amp;#8217;ve seen GlotPress in action, and it&amp;#8217;s pretty amazing.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h4&gt;WordPress.org&lt;/h4&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://wordpress.org&quot;&gt;WordPress.org&lt;/a&gt; is a central hub for the WordPress community. Matt highlighted some of the work that&amp;#8217;s been going on this past year around languages, support forums, and more. He also says that new work will be going into P2/O2, which are used for the &lt;a href=&quot;https://make.wordpress.org&quot;&gt;Make WordPress&lt;/a&gt; blogs.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;And he gave attention to the new WordPress plugin repository, which finally uses WordPress itself, and has a whole new design. You can see the new design in action on the new &lt;a href=&quot;https://wordpress.org/plugins-wp/&quot;&gt;demo site&lt;/a&gt;, which should role out to the main Plugins directory soon.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;WordPress in all languages&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;WordPress 4.6 was available in 50 languages the day it was released. And the top 10 plugins are 82% translated in the top 12 languages used in WordPress.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Language packs have been a huge help in helping translate plugins as a community project on Translate.WordPress.org, rather than having to ship translations inside the plugin itself.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;1,598 plugins are now using language packs, and 1,224 themes use them. This is huge for the future of WordPress working great in every language.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Also, in WordPress 4.7, we&amp;#8217;ll see per-user language choices.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;Learning JavaScript Deeply&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Last year&amp;#8217;s homework for the community was to learn JavaScript deeply. He says that WordPress is 28% JavaScript now, which hasn&amp;#8217;t changed, but he says we&amp;#8217;ve still made a lot of progress.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Matt gave himself a personal challenge to learn JavaScript, and he said that 364 days into this challenge, he submitted his first patch to Calypso (Automattic&amp;#8217;s WordPress administration interface). He said, learning JavaScript and becoming as native with JavaScript as with PHP is going to be really important &amp;#8212; especially as the REST API gets included in WordPress 4.7.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;WordPress Growth Council&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Matt recently posted about a WordPress Growth Council to help WordPress grow and maintain marketshare.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;He says that what got WordPress to where it is today, won&amp;#8217;t get WordPress to where it can be tomorrow. He blogged about this &lt;a href=&quot;https://ma.tt/2016/12/wp-growth-council/&quot;&gt;new growth council&lt;/a&gt;, which folks can apply for, which will help guide product direction in WordPress going forward.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Matt actually said in Post Status Slack recently that if WordPress doesn&amp;#8217;t make changes to the interface and otherwise, he&amp;#8217;d expect WordPress marketshare would begin to decline by 2018.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;HTTPS &amp;amp; PHP7&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;11.45% of WordPress websites are now served via HTTPS. Matt talked last year about how LetsEncrypt and PHP7 were going to be a big deal, but they&amp;#8217;ve turned out to be, &amp;#8220;huge.&amp;#8221; And WordPress will now start applying progressive enhancement techniques for WordPress websites.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;WordPress.com is now fully on PHP7, which he says was an enormous accomplishment. He&amp;#8217;s also announced that &lt;a href=&quot;https://wordpress.org/about/requirements/&quot;&gt;WordPress.org will now recommend&lt;/a&gt; PHP7 by default.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;h3&gt;Calypso&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Matt gave some updates on &lt;a href=&quot;https://developer.wordpress.com/calypso/&quot;&gt;Calypso&amp;#8217;s&lt;/a&gt; adoption since it was released last year. He says that 68% of posts on WordPress.com are now written in Calypso. 17% of posts are written via a mobile device, and only 15% of users are using the WordPress admin. For reference, Calypso is the default method of publishing on WordPress.com now, so that includes the desktop website, desktop app, and mobile app.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Matt says that building Calypso is like, &amp;#8220;building a plane while it&amp;#8217;s flying.&amp;#8221; And while it&amp;#8217;s hard, he says it&amp;#8217;s worth it, but it&amp;#8217;s like rebuilding WordPress &amp;#8212; which took 13 years to do &amp;#8212; in only two years.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;The future of Calypso includes making it &amp;#8220;plugin aware&amp;#8221;, so that prominent plugins (most Automattic plugins included) would be recognized and manageable via Calypso.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;In fact, Calypso is plugin aware today, as the merge has just happened. So now plugins can include custom code to be manageable via Calypso.
